label: eucalypt_box
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Box" type bark.

label: eucalypt_gum
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Gum" type bark.

label: eucalypt_stocking
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Gum" type bark above a rough barked stocking.

label: eucalypt_ironbark
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Ironbark" type bark.

label: eucalypt_peppermint
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Peppermint" type bark.

label: eucalypt_stringybark
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Stringy" type bark.

label: eucalypt_ribbonbark
description: Eucalyptus, Corymbia or Angophora taxa with "Gum" type bark that sheds in ribbons.

label: calcicole
description: Plants are tolerant of basic soils, such as calcareous sands and limestone derived soils.

label: calcifuge
description: Plants are intolerant of basic soils. (Synonyms, acidophilous)

label: ground
description: Graminoids, herbs and ferns reaching maximum heights of c. 0.2-1 m.

label: mid
description: Shrubs reaching maximum heights of c. 1-2 m.

label: upper
description: Tall shrubs reaching maximum heights of c. 3-5 m.

label: post_fire_ephemeral
description: Taxa that avoid competition with other strata by rapidly completing their life cycle after fire; a sub-category of 'ground'.

label: foliaceous
description: Cotyledons are photosynthetic and function as leaves.

label: reserve
description: Cotyledons function as energy reserve organs.

label: cryptocotylar
description: A type of seed germination in which the cotyledons remain within the seed coat at germination.

label: phanerocotylar
description: A type of seed germination in which the cotyledons emerge from the seed coat.

label: glabrous
description: Cotyledons lack hairs.

label: hairy
description: Cotyledons have hairs.

label: epigeal
description: Germinant with one or more cotyledons emerging aboveground.

label: hypogeal
description: Germinant with all cotyledons remaining belowground.

label: aril
description: Fleshy outgrowth of a seed, that often attracts animals like birds or ants.

label: bristles
description: Bristle-like projections. Trait value includes awns, which are slender, bristle-like projections in some grasses.

label: bracts_and_glumes
description: When the bracts below the inflorescence are persistent and functional as dispersal appendages. This includes persistent glumes, the modified membranous bracts in the family Poaceae that surround the spikelet of a grass.

label: elaiosome
description: Fleshy (often fatty) appendage on seeds that attracts ants.

label: fleshy_reward
description: Broad term that includes a suite of appendages that provides a fleshy reward to attract dispersers; highest level of resolution available for some studies.

label: floating_seed
description: Seed that is dispersed by floating on water.

label: flotation_scales
description: Scales enhancing flotation, thereby assisting with dispersal.

label: floral_parts
description: When some plant floral parts (the petals, sepals, or style) are persistent and aid in seed and fruit dispersal. This is a broad term not explicitly suggesting a dispersal mechanism.

label: hairs
description: Modified hairs that aid in seed dispersal.

label: hooks
description: A rear-facing point, as in a fish hook that aids in seed and fruit dispersal.

label: inflated_parts
description: When some part of the seed, fruit, or associated tissues is inflated, aiding in seed or fruit dispersal.

label: none
description: When a fruit and associated tissues lack any dispersal appendages. Includes exarillate and taxa with explicitly deciduous pappus.

label: pappus
description: The calyx in Asteraceae that has been modified into bristles, hairs, scales or awns that are attached to the apex of the fruit. Taxa assigned this trait value have a persistent pappus that aids in dispersal, often, but not exclusively through wind dispersal. The pappus can also assist with flotation.

label: plumose
description: Fruit, seed, style, or other floral component that is plumose and assists with dispersal.

label: receptacle
description: Fleshy receptacle that aids in dispersal.

label: sarcotesta
description: Fleshy seed coat that aids in dispersal.

label: spines
description: Spines that aid in dispersal.

label: tumbleweed
description: Plant growth form, whereby the aboveground plant component detaches from the roots and is readily rolled by wind across the ground, aiding in dispersal.

label: wings
description: Referring to wing-like seed extensions that aid in wind dispersal.

label: wing_or_plume
description: Broad term that includes a suite of appendages that aid in wind dispersal; highest level of resolution available for some studies.

label: anemochory
description: Diaspore is dispersed by wind. (Synonyms, wind)

label: anthrochory
description: Diaspore is dispersed by humans, either intentionally or unintentionally.

label: atelochory
description: Diaspore dispersal is prevented. (Synonyms, antitelochory)

label: autochory
description: Diaspore is dispersed by methods originating from the parent plant or diaspore.

label: ballistic
description: Seeds are launched away from the plant by explosion as soon as the seed capsule opens.

label: barochory
description: Diaspores are dispersed without assistance. (Synonyms, gravity, mobile, unassisted, passive)

label: chamaechory
description: Diaspore is dispersed by being rolled along ground surface by wind.

label: endozoochory
description: Diaspore is ingested by animals, either intentionally or accidentally, then transported before being deposited. (Synonyms, ingestion)

label: epizoochory
description: Diaspore is dispersed by accidentally attaching itself to the outside of an animal vector. (Synonyms, ectozoochory, exozoochory)

label: hydrochory
description: Diaspore is dispersed on the surface of water. (Synonyms, water)

label: myrmecochory
description: Diaspores have elaiosomes (specialised nutritious appendages) that make them attractive for capture, transport and use by ants or related insects.

label: undefined
description: Dispersal mechanism unknown. (Synonyms, unknown)

label: zoochory
description: Diaspore is dispersed by animals, by an undescribed mechanism.

label: fruit
description: Dispersal unit is a fruit.

label: seed
description: Dispersal unit is a seed.

label: spore
description: Dispersal unit is a spore.

label: seedling
description: Dispersal unit is a seedling. (Synonyms, viviparous)

label: indigenous_people
description: Indigenous people disperse the fruit through traditional practices.

label: abiotic
description: Fruits are dispersed by unspecified abiotic mechanisms.

label: ants
description: Ants are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: animals
description: Animals are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: bats
description: Bats are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: birds
description: Birds are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: cassowaries
description: Cassowaries, in contrast to smaller flying birds, are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: fish
description: Fish are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: floods
description: Floods are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: flying_vertebrates
description: Flying birds and bats are important fruit dispersal agents.

label: flying_foxes
description: Flying foxes are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: garden_refuse
description: Fruit are dispersed through garden refuse.

label: insects
description: Insects are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: invertebrates
description: Invertebrates are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: mammals
description: Mammals are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: mammals_domestic
description: Domesticated ammals are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: non-flying_vertebrates
description: Mammals and non-flying birds (i.e. cassowary, emu) are important fruit dispersal agents.

label: passive
description: There is no special dispersal agent.

label: rain
description: Rain is an important fruit dispersal agent; the diaspore is propelled by action of rain on plant structure or the wetting of the plant structure by rain or dew.

label: rodents
description: Rodents are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: vehicles
description: Vehicles are an important dispersal agent, such as through mud on tyres.

label: vertebrates
description: Vertebrates are an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: wind
description: Wind is an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: water
description: Water is an important fruit dispersal agent.

label: water_currents
description: Water currents are an important fruit dispersal agent; the diaspore may be either floating or submerged in fresh/saltwater currents.

label: morphophysiological_dormancy
description: Seeds exhibit morphophysiological dormancy, with both morphological and physiological dormancy mechanisms that must be overcome.

label: morphological_dormancy
description: Seeds exhibit morphological dormancy, generally because an underdeveloped embryo needs to grow.

label: non_dormant
description: Seeds are non-dormant.

label: physical_dormancy
description: Seeds exhibit physical dormancy, due to one or more water-impermeable layers in the seed coat.

label: physiological_dormancy
description: Seeds exhibit physiological dormancy, whereby chemical changes are required within the seed to break dormancy, including temperature stratification and after-ripening.

label: colourless
description: Colourless embryo.

label: green
description: Green embryo.

label: aquatic_taxon
description: Plants rarely or never experience fires because they are aquatic.

label: fire_avoidance_among_rocks
description: Plants rarely experience fires because their habitat is restricted to rocky outcrops or rock pavement.

label: fire_avoidance_near_water
description: Plants rarely or never experience fires because their habitat is close to a body of water.

label: fire_avoidance_in_swamp
description: Plants rarely experience fires because their habitat is usually saturated, but populations can be catastrophically impacted during severe droughts when the swamps dry out.

label: seasonal_fire_avoidance
description: Plants avoid fire by only have above-ground parts during seasons when fire is rare or absent, but populations can be catastrophically impacted if fire occurs during an atypical season.

label: fire_killed
description: Fewer than 30% of plants resprout following a fire with 100% leaf scorch. (Synonym, fire-sensitive)

label: resprouts
description: More than 70% of plants resprout following a fire with 100% leaf scorch.

label: partial_resprouting
description: Between 30-70% of plants resprout following a fire with 100% leaf scorch.

label: juvenile_fire_killed
description: Few to no juvenile plants resprout following fire with 100% leaf scorch.

label: juvenile_resprout
description: More than 50% of juvenile plants survive and resprout following fire with 100% leaf scorch.

label: juvenile_moderate_fire_killed
description: 25-50% of juvenile plants resprout following fire with 100% leaf scorch.

label: establish_post_fire
description: Seedling establishment occurs following fire.

label: establish_post_disturbance
description: Seedling establishment occurs following disturbances that increase light levels at the ground surface, but the type of disturbance is not documented.

label: establish_anytime
description: Seedlings can establish immediately following a disturbance and in later years as vegetation ages, right thru to mature and over-mature vegetation

label: establish_intermediate_to_mature_vegetation
description: Seedlings require some environmental characteristics not found in vegetation straight after fires to establish, for they cannot establish within the first season or two after fire but can establish in older vegetation (including mature to over-mature vegetation).

label: post_fire_recruitment
description: Plants that germinate post-fire.

label: post_fire_recruitment_absent
description: Plants that do not show increased seeding following fire.

label: fire_dependent_flowering
description: Plants predominantly flower after a fire, usually within the first 1-4 growing seasons following the fire.

label: fire_enhanced_flowering
description: Flowering is enhanced after a fire, with plants flowering more prolifically for the first 1-4 growing seasons following the fire.

label: fire_independent_flowering
description: Flowering is independent of fire, with the magnitude of flowers produced by plants unchanged following a fire.

label: fire_suppressed_flowering
description: Flowering is suppressed or absent after a fire, with plants producing fewer flowers for at least the first 1-4 growing seasons following the fire.

label: fire_retardant
description: Plants protected from fire by fire retardant in their bark, stems, or other tissues.

label: fire_retardant_bark
description: Plants protected from fire by fire retardant in their bark.

label: thick_bark
description: Plants protected from fire by thick bark.

label: blue_purple
description: Flower colour is blue or purple.

label: green
description: Flower colour is green.

label: pink
description: Flower colour is pink.

label: red_brown
description: Flower colour is red or brown.

label: white_cream
description: Flower colour is white or cream.

label: yellow_orange
description: Flower colour is yellow or orange.

label: grey
description: Flower colour is grey.

label: black
description: Flower colour is black.

label: white
description: Perianth colour is white.

label: yellow
description: Perianth colour is yellow.

label: orange
description: Perianth colour is orange.

label: red
description: Perianth colour is red.

label: pink
description: Perianth colour is pink.

label: purple
description: Perianth colour is purple.

label: blue
description: Perianth colour is blue.

label: green
description: Perianth colour is green.

label: grey
description: Perianth colour is grey.

label: brown
description: Perianth colour is brown.

label: black
description: Perianth colour is black.

label: up
description: Flower orientation is vertical, with the floral entrance pointing up.

label: lateral
description: Flower orientation is horizontal, with the floral entrance perpendicular to main vertical axis.

label: down
description: Flower orientation is pendant, with the floral entrance pointing down.

label: mixed
description: Flower orientation is mixed, with different flowers exhibiting different orientations.

label: rain
description: Plants increase flowering in response to rain, but the time of year is not specified.

label: rain_obligate
description: Plants only flower following rain events.

label: rain_all_year
description: Plants increase flowering in response to rain at any time of the year.

label: rain_summer
description: Plants increase flowering in response to summer rains.

label: rain_autumn
description: Plants increase flowering in response to autumn rains.

label: rain_winter
description: Plants increase flowering in response to winter rains.

label: rain_spring
description: Plants increase flowering in response to spring rains.

label: floods
description: Plants increase flowering in response to floods.

label: fire
description: Plants increase flowering in response to fires.

label: bisexual
description: Hermaphrodite; flowers with both male and female reproductive organs.

label: incompletely_unisexual
description: Male flowers with pistillodes and/or female flowers with staminodes.

label: unisexual
description: Flowers with either male or female reproductive organs.

label: inferior
description: Flower with inferior ovary, where the ovary is embedded in the receptacle and therefore located below the insertion level of the remaining floral organs.

label: superior
description: Flower with superior ovary, where the ovary is positioned above the insertion level of the remaining floral organs.

label: half_inferior
description: Flower where the receptacle is surrounded by the ovary to its mid-level.

label: one_quarter_inferior
description: Flower where the receptacle surrounds up to one quarter of the ovary.

label: three_quarters_inferior
description: Flower where the receptacle surrounds more than three quarters of the ovary.

label: actinomorphic_general
description: Perianth displaying radial symmetry.

label: actinomorphic_rotational
description: Perianth that can be equally divided into three or more identical sections that, when rotated around the center of the flower by some number of degrees, exactly match each other in orientation and shape.

label: actinomorphic_strictly_polysymmetric
description: Polysymmetry, with three or more planes of bilateral symmetry.

label: actinomorphic_spiral
description: Perianth lacking a distinct plane of symmetry because their perianth parts are spirally arranged.

label: asymmetric
description: Perianth lacking any planes of symmetry.

label: disymmetric
description: Perianth with two orthogonal planes of bilateral symmetry.

label: zygomorphic
description: Monosymmetric, with a single plane of bilateral symmetry.

label: irregular
description: Perianth parts lacking any symmetrical organisation.

label: spiral
description: Perianth parts organised along a continuous spiral, usually with wide divergence angles more or less equal to 137.5 degrees, the Fibonacci 'golden angle'.

label: whorled
description: Perianth parts organised in one or more whorls.

label: undifferentiated
description: Flower were all tepals are alike, including flowers with a single, undifferentiated whorl.

label: marked_differentiation_outer_sepaloid_inner_petaloid
description: A typical flower with a distinct calyx and corolla.

label: marked_differentiation_among_petaloid_tepals
description: A flower with tepals that all resemble petals, but with marked differentiation between whorls of tepals.

label: marked_differentiation_among_sepaloid_tepals
description: A flower with tepals that all resemble sepals, but with marked differentiation between whorls of tepals.

label: marked_differentiation
description: A flower with marked differentiation between whorls, but without an indication if the perianth whorls are petals, sepals, or tepals.

label: continuous_differentiation_outer_sepaloid_inner_petaloid
description: A flower with multiple whorls, where there is continuous differentiation between the outer sepaloid parts and the inner petaloid parts.

label: continuous_differentiation_among_petaloid_tepals
description: A flower with series of tepals that all resemble petals, which display continuous, gradual differentiation between whorls.

label: continuous_differentiation_among_sepaloid_tepals
description: A flower with series of tepals that all resemble sepals, which display continuous, gradual differentiation between whorls.

label: weak_differentiation
description: A flower with weak between whorls, but without an indication if the perianth whorls are petals, sepals, or tepals.

label: very_weak_differentiation
description: A flower with very weak between whorls, but without an indication if the perianth whorls are petals, sepals, or tepals.

label: absent
description: No filaments present

label: present_general
description: Filaments present, with no specific defining characteristics.

label: long_and_narrow
description: Filaments have a long and narrow shape. (Synonyms, filiform, slender)

label: short_and_narrow
description: Filaments have a short and narrow shape; subsessile anthers.

label: long_and_wide
description: Filaments have a long and wide laminar shape.

label: short_and_wide
description: Filaments have a short and wide laminar shape.

label: long_and_very_wide
description: Filaments have a long and very wide shape; for instance, the petal-like (outer) stamens of Nymphaea.

label: petaloid
description: Filaments are long and wide and colorful, e.g. Canna.

label: fused_into_synandrium
description: Filament structure formed when stamens fused together.

label: fused_into_fascicle_stalks
description: Special case where the stamens are fused into the stalk of a fascicle of flowers.

label: long_and_narrow_divided_in_two
description: Filaments have a long and narrow shape that is divided in two; e.g. Adoxa.

label: short_general
description: Filament is short relative to the anther.

label: apical
description: When thecae are positioned in a transverse position at the tip of the connective and thus dehisce upward in the flower (e.g., Sinofranchetia, Endress and Hufford, 1989).

label: extrorse
description: When the stomia of the thecae face the floral periphery.

label: introrse
description: When the stomia of the thecae face the floral centre.

label: latrorse
description: When pollen is released toward the side (i.e., toward neighbouring anthers).

label: basifixed
description: Filament attached to the base of the connective. Laminar stamens are classified as basifixed.

label: dorsifixed
description: Filament attached to the dorsal side of the anther.

label: dorsifixed_at_base
description: Filament attached to the dorsal side of the anther, at the base.

label: ventrifixed
description: Filament attached to the ventral side of the anther.

label: longitudinal_slit
description: Anther with longitudinal slits that extend along the entire length of each theca.

label: poricidal
description: Anther where dehiscence of longitudinal slits is incomplete, with pollen exiting via a small pore at the tip.

label: pores_many
description: Anther with pollen exiting from many pores along its length.

label: h_valvate
description: Anther with two valves on longitudinal hinges, opening horizontally as salon doors; when the stomium bifurcates at its distal and/or proximal end and thus a valve is formed.

label: flap_valvate
description: Anther with one or more flap-like valves on horizontal hinges, opening vertically.

label: transverse_slit
description: Anther with horizontal slit.

label: short_basal_slits
description: Anther where dehiscence of longitudinal slits is incomplete and only occurs over a short extent at the base of the theca.

label: short_central_slits
description: Anther where dehiscence of longitudinal slits is incomplete and only occurs over a short extent at the center of the theca.

label: short_apical_slits
description: Anther where dehiscence of longitudinal slits is incomplete and only occurs over a short extent at the apical end of the theca.

label: t_valvate
description: Anther with T-shaped stomium; reduced transverse slit at base.

label: common_stomium_confluent_thecae
description: The two thecae of a single anther are fused at one end with a single pore through which pollen exits.

label: circular
description: Anther with a transverse slit that goes entirely around the anther.

label: absent
description: Apical connective extensions are lacking.

label: short_extension
description: Connective extension less than a third of the length of anther.

label: long_extension
description: Connective extension more than a third but less than length of anther; e.g. Idiospermum australiense.

label: very_long_extension
description: Connective extension more than length of anther; e.g. Galbulimima belgraveana.

label: present_general
description: Apical connective extensions are present but no information on their length relative to the anthers.

label: whorled
description: Stamens and staminodes arranged in whorls.

label: spiral
description: Stamens and staminodes have a spiral arrangement.

label: irregular
description: Stamens and staminodes have an irregular arrangement.

label: one_whorl
description: Flowers with a single whorl of carpels.

label: two_or_more_whorls
description: Flowers with two or more whorls of carpels.

label: spiral
description: Flowers with carpels in a spiral arrangement.

label: absent
description: Stigma sessile.

label: present_length_and_shape_unknown
description: Style present but shape unknown.

label: present_short_and_thick
description: Style present, and short and thick.

label: present_short_and_narrow
description: Style present, and short and narrow, including short filiform styles.

label: present_long_and_wide
description: Style present, and long and wide.

label: present_long_and_narrow
description: Style present, and long and narrow, including long filiform styles.

label: present_petaloid
description: Style present and petaloid.

label: continuous
description: When the style is an apical extension of carpel with decurrent stigma.

label: axile
description: Ovules are placed in the angle between carpel flanks in the center of the ovary; in syncarpous gynoecia.

label: apical
description: Ovules attach at the top of the ovary; pendulous; in syncarpous gynoecia and apocarpous and unicarpellate gynoecia.

label: basal
description: Ovules attach at the base of the ovary; in syncarpous gynoecia and apocarpous and unicarpellate gynoecia.

label: parietal
description: Ovules attach to the ovary wall where two carpels meet; in syncarpous gynoecia.

label: marginal
description: Ovules attach along the ventral slit; in apocarpous and unicarpellate gynoecia.

label: free_central
description: Ovules are attached to a central column that emerges from the base of the ovary and protrudes into the non-septate ovary; in syncarpous gynoecia.

label: laminar
description: When there is more than one series of ovules at the flanks of a carpel; in syncarpous gynoecia and apocarpous and unicarpellate gynoecia.

label: absent
description: Pollen that lacks an aperture.

label: colporus
description: Pollen aperture shape that combines the groove of colpate and the pore of porate apertures.

label: colpus
description: Pollen aperture shape is elongate and grooved and may be positioned globally or equatorially.

label: pore
description: Pollen aperture shape is round and pore-like and may be positioned globally or equatorially.

label: ring_like
description: Aperture that completely encircles the pollen.

label: spiraperturate
description: Pollen grain with one or more spiral apertures.

label: sulcus
description: Pollen aperture shape is elongate and grooved and positioned at the pole.

label: syncolpus
description: Pollen grain with two or more simple (or compound) colpi, the ends of which join at the pole.

label: ulcus
description: Pollen aperture shape is round and pore-like and positioned at the pole.

label: pink
description: Fruit's exocarp is pink.

label: red
description: Fruit's exocarp is red.

label: orange
description: Fruit's exocarp is orange.

label: yellow
description: Fruit's exocarp is yellow.

label: green
description: Fruit's exocarp is green.

label: blue
description: Fruit's exocarp is blue.

label: purple
description: Fruit's exocarp is purple.

label: white
description: Fruit's exocarp is white.

label: cream
description: Fruit's exocarp is cream.

label: brown
description: Fruit's exocarp is brown.

label: black
description: Fruit's exocarp is black.

label: grey
description: Fruit's exocarp is grey.

label: achene
description: A simple, dry, indehiscent fruit with a single seed that is attached to the pericarp at one point only. (Synonyms, cypsela)

label: anthocarp
description: A ripened ovary surrounded by attached accessory floral tissues; the floral tissues may be fleshy or dry. (Synonyms, accessory_fruit, pseudocarp, diclesium)

label: berry
description: A simple, indehiscent fruit with one to many seeds embedded in a fleshy pericarp.

label: capsule
description: A dry, dehiscent fruit composed of two or more united carpels; different types of capsules distinguished by type of dehiscence (e.g. valves, slits, pores).

label: caryopsis
description: A simple, dry, indehiscent fruit with a single seed which is fused to the pericarp at one point only; the fruit type of all Poaceae (Synonyms, grain)

label: compound_fruit_other
description: A fruit derived from more than one flower. (Synonyms, aggregate_fruit)

label: drupe
description: A simple indehiscent fruit with a hard, stony endocarp and a fleshy mesocarp.

label: follicle
description: A dry, dehiscent fruit derived from a single carpel that splits along one suture.

label: legume
description: A dry, dehiscent fruit derived from a single carpel that splits along two sutures; applies to Fabaceae. (Synonyms, pod)

label: legume_indehiscent
description: A dry, indehiscent fruit derived from a single carpel; applies to Fabaceae.

label: mericarp
description: A fruitlet (seed-containing portion of a fruit) that is a half-carpel; the individual fruitlets separate from one another at maturity; a specific type of schizocarp. (In some datasets, term likely refers to any fruitlet derived from a portion of a schizocarp that separates at maturity, not explicitly just a half-carpel.)

label: multiple_fruit
description: A fruit composed of several fruitlets developing from a single flower (e.g. raspberries, magnolias); fruits developing from more than one flower are included under compound (aggregate) fruits. (Synonym, apocarp)

label: nut
description: A simple, dry, indehiscent fruit with a single seed and a hard pericarp.

label: nutlet
description: A diminutive of nut, referring to a simple, dry, indehiscent structure with a single seed that might be an entire fruit (nut; monocarp) or a portion of a fruit, such as the individual components derived from an apocarp (fruit with multiple unfused ovaries) or schizocarp (fruit with multiple ovaries that separate at maturity).

label: pepo
description: A fleshy fruit derived from a single ovary that is divided into several carpels, has multiple seeds, and has a tough rind when mature.

label: pome
description: A fleshy fruit with the bulk of the fleshy tissue derived from flora tissue that surrounds the inferior ovary.

label: pyrene
description: A fleshy fruit in which the seed(s) are covered by a hard layer of endocarp.

label: samara
description: A winged, dry fruit.

label: schizocarp
description: Category that includes all fruits derived from a compound pistil that separate into individual carpellary constituents at maturity; broad terms that includes dry and fleshy fruits, some with accessory tissues, others without. The individual seed-containing units that a schizocarp breaks apart into include mericarps, nutlets, and fruitlets.

label: silique
description: A type of capsule (dry, dehiscent fruit) where the fruit is divided into two parts by a thin partition; more than three times as long as wide; applies to Brassicaceae (Synonyms, silicle, siliqua)

label: strobilus
description: A modified reproductive shoot system found in many nonflowering plants, especially gymnosperms, comprised of overlapping bracts (scales). (Synonyms, cone)

label: syncarp
description: A compound fruit produced by the adhesion of the fruits from several flowers.

label: syconium
description: A fleshy compound fruit, in which the fruitlets are enclosed in accessory material, such as the hollow-centered fruits of Moraceae. (Synonyms, synconium, fig)

label: utricle
description: A bladdery or inflated dry fruit with a single seed; essential an achene in which the pericarp is significantly larger than the mature seed.

label: dry
description: Fruits are dry when mature and fresh.

label: fleshy
description: Fruits are fleshy when mature and fresh.

label: dehiscent
description: Fruits are dehiscent when mature.

label: indehiscent
description: Fruits are indehiscent when mature.

label: dry
description: Diaspores where the true fruit, accessory tissues and dispersal appendages are all dry when mature.

label: fleshy
description: Diaspores where either the true fruit, accessory tissues or dispersal appendages are fleshy when mature.

label: after_ripening
description: Seed germinates more readily after a period of warm, dry storage.

label: chemical_treatment
description: Seed germinates more readily after a chemical treatment.

label: cold
description: Seed germinates more readily after cold treatment.

label: dark
description: Seed germinates more readily after being stored in the dark.

label: heat
description: Seed germinates more readily after being heated.

label: heat_lethal
description: Seed is heat sensitive. (A fire response, more than a treatment to break dormancy.)

label: heat+smoke
description: Seed germinates more readily after a treatment that merges heat and smoke.

label: imbibe_hot
description: Seed germinates more readily after being soaked in hot water; water temperature usually between 70 deg C to just below boiling.

label: leaching
description: Seed germinates more readily after leaching out certain chemicals.

label: light
description: Seed germinates more readily after light exposure.

label: mycorrhizae
description: Seed germinates more readily if infected by a mycorrhizal symbiont.

label: none
description: No treatment required for seed to display high germination rates.

label: rain
description: Seed germinates more readily after rain.

label: scarify
description: Seed coat is removed, nicked, or otherwise punctured to increase germination.

label: smoke
description: Seed germinates more readily after being subjected to a smoke treatment; includes smoked water.

label: stratification
description: Seed germinates more readily after being stored in moist conditions; not specified if the treatment was `cold stratification` or `warm stratification`.

label: stratification_cold
description: Seed germinates more readily after a period of cold, wet storage.

label: stratification_warm
description: Seed germinates more readily after a period of warm, wet storage.

label: glabrous
description: Hypocotyl lacks hairs.

label: hairy
description: Hypocotyl has hairs.

label: not_applicable
description: Taxa is not typically confronted with being inundated and its response is unknown.

label: less_than_1_month
description: Taxa able to tolerate being inundated for less than 1 month.

label: 1-6_months
description: Taxa able to tolerate being inundated for 1-6 months.

label: greater_than_6_months
description: Taxa able to tolerate being inundated for  more than 6 months.

label: aquatic
description: Taxa truly aquatic and able to be permanently inundated.

label: terrestrial_dry
description: Species which germinate, grow and reproduce where there is no surface water and the water table is below the soil surface. (Dry species; Tdr)

label: terrestrial_damp
description: Species which germinate, grow and reproduce on saturated soil. (Damp species; Tda)

label: amphibious_fluctuation_tolerators_emergent
description: Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions, which tolerate variation in water level, and which grow with their basal portions under water and reproduce out of water. (Emergent species; ATe)

label: amphibious_fluctuation_tolerators_low
description: Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions, which tolerate variation in water level, which are low-growing and tolerate complete submersion when water-levels rise. (Low-growing species; ATl)

label: amphibious_fluctuation_responders_plastic
description: Species which germinate in flooded conditions, grow in both flooded and damp conditions, reproduce above the surface of the water, and which have morphological plasticity (e.g. heterophylly) in response to water-level variation. (Morphologically plastic species; ARp)

label: amphibious_fluctuation_responders_floating
description: Species which germinate in flooded conditions, grow in both flooded and damp conditions, reproduce above the surface of the water, and which have floating leaves when inundated. (Species with floating leaves; ARf)

label: amphibious
description: Species which germinate in damp or flooded conditions and can grow in or our of water.

label: submerged
description: Species which germinate, grow and reproduce underwater. (S

label: pendulous
description: Leaves are pendulous.

label: not_pendulous
description: Leaves are not pendulous.

label: decussate
description: When sequential pairs of opposite leaves attach at right angles to the pair above or below.

label: distichous
description: When alternate or opposite leaves are arranged in two opposite rows.

label: scattered
description: When leaves are attached along the entire length of stem.

label: spiral
description: When alternate leaves are attached in a progressive spiral pattern along the stem.

label: fasciculate
description: A tight bundle or cluster of leaves attaches to the stem in a single location, generally due to the shortening of internodes. (Synonym, tufted)

label: clustered
description: When leaves are in any type of cluster, where the type of cluster is not further specified. The leaves may be clustered toward the base of the plant (a rosette), toward the top of the plant, toward the end of branches, or in distinct tuft (fascicles), but more information is not provided.

label: clustered_basal
description: When leaves are clustered or crowded to the base of the stem, arranged in a rosette or other basal clustering. (Synonym, rosette)

label: crowded
description: When internode length varies considerably along a stem, such that leaves appear crowded or tufted. (Synonym, congested)

label: rosette
description: When leaves radiate from a central point at or near ground level.

label: imbricate
description: When leaves lay tightly against the stem and are overlapping.

label: alternate
description: A single leaf is attached at each stem node.

label: opposite
description: A pair of leaves are attached opposite to one another at each stem node.

label: whorled
description: Three or more leaves are attached at each stem node, arranged in a symmetrical pattern around the stem. (Synonyms, verticillate)

label: glaucous
description: Mature (fully expanded) leaves on adult plants have a waxy coating, giving them a glaucous appearance. (Synonyms, waxy bloom, pruinose)

label: not_glaucous
description: Mature (fully expanded) leaves on adult plants do not have a glaucous appearance.

label: glabrous
description: Mature (fully expanded) leaves on adult plants do not have hairs (trichomes).

label: hairy
description: Mature (fully expanded) leaves on adult plants have hairs (trichomes).

label: glabrous
description: Immature (still expanding) leaves do not have hairs (trichomes).

label: hairy
description: Immature (still expanding) leaves have hairs (trichomes).

label: glabrous
description: Juvenile phase leaves do not have hairs (trichomes).

label: hairy
description: Juvenile phase leaves have hairs (trichomes).

label: entire
description: Leaf margin lacks projections or indentations that extend less than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib.

label: toothed
description: Leaf margin has small projections or lobes along the edge of the leaf lamina. This is a broad term that includes serrate, dentate, and crenulate.

label: toothed_serrate
description: Type of toothed leaf margin with sharp teeth that are angled toward the tip of the leaf. (Synonyms, saw-toothed)

label: toothed_dentate
description: Type of toothed leaf margin with sharp teeth that point outwards at right angles to the leaf margin.

label: toothed_crenate
description: Type of toothed leaf margin with teeth that are rounded or obtuse, rather than having a sharp apex. [PO:0025519]

label: involute
description: Leaf margins along the side of the leaf are rolled upward, such that the margin of the adaxial (upper) leaf surface is rolled inward. (Synonym, inrolled, incurved)

label: revolute
description: Leaf margins along the side of the leaf are rolled under or downward, such that the margin of the abaxial (lower) leaf surface is rolled inward. [PATO:0001963] (Synonym, recurved)

label: flat
description: Leaf lamina, including margins, is a 2-dimensional plane. [PATO:0000407]

label: undulate
description: Leaf margins are wavy in their 2-dimensional plane. (Synonyms, wavy, rippled, sinuate)

label: concave
description: A longitudinal posture term indicating the leaf lamina is curved upward along the central axis, such that the upper leaf lamina surface is concave.

label: conduplicate
description: A longitudinal posture term indicating the leaf lamina is folded upward along the central axis. (Synonym, folded)

label: convex
description: A longitudinal posture term indicating the leaf lamina is curved downward along the central axis, such that the lower leaf lamina surface is concave. (Synonym, concavoconvex, planoconvex)

label: convolute
description: Leaf lamina is contorted. (Synonym, twisted)

label: flat
description: The leaf lamina is a 2-dimensional plane.

label: incurved
description: Leaf tip is curved upward.

label: involute
description: A longitudinal posture term indicating the outer portions of the leaf lamina are rolled inward or upward.

label: plicate
description: Leaf margin is pleated, with a series of longitudinal folds.

label: recurved
description: Leaf tip is curved outward or downward. [PATO:0002211]

label: revolute
description: A longitudinal posture term indicating the outer portions of the leaf lamina are rolled outward or downward.

label: undulate
description: The leaf lamina surface is rippled or wavy in its 2-dimensional plane. [PATO:0000967]  (Synonyms, wavy, rippled, sinuate)

label: unlobed
description: Leaf margin lacks projections or indentations that extend more than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib.

label: lobed
description: Leaf margin has incisions, either rounded or sharp-tipped, that extend more than 1/8 of the distance to the midrib.

label: lobed_deep
description: Leaf margin with lobes that extend more than halfway to the midrib. (Synonyms, parted, divided)

label: lobed_shallow
description: Leaf margin with lobes that extend less than halfway to the midrib. (Synonyms, cleft, sinuate)

label: simple
description: A leaf with a single undivided blade. [PO:0020042]

label: compound
description: A leaf that is divided into multiple leaflets. [PO:0020043]

label: pinnately_lobed
description: Leaf with divisions that are symmetrical across a central axis, usually the midvein.

label: palmately_lobed
description: Leaf with divisions that radiate from a single point, usually the basal junction of major veins.

label: pinnatifid
description: Leaf with lobes that extend less than half-way to the midrib.

label: bipinnatifid
description: Leaf that is twice pinnatifid, with two series of lobes that extend less than half-way to the midrib.

label: pinnatipartite
description: Leaf with lobes that extend more than half-way to the midrib.

label: pinnatisect
description: Leaf with lobes that extend nearly to the midrib but the divisions are not separated into distinct leaflets.

label: bipinnatipartite
description: Leaf that is twice pinnatipartite, with two series of lobes that extend more than half-way to the midrib.

label: bipinnatisect
description: Leaf that is twice pinnatisect, with two series of lobes that extend nearly to the midrib but the divisions are not separated into distinct leaflets.

label: trichotomously_lobed
description: Leaf divided repeatedly into three lobes.

label: dichotomously_lobed
description: Leaf divided repeatedly into two lobes.

label: bipartite
description: Leaf divided into two lobes.

label: tripartite
description: Leaf divided into three lobes.

label: pinnately_compound
description: Leaf divided into leaflets that attach along a central axis. [PATO_0000410]

label: palmately_compound
description: Leaf divided into leaflets that attach to a central point. (Synonyms, digitate)

label: bipinnate
description: Leaf that is twice pinnate, having pinnate leaflets that are themselves pinnately divided.

label: tripinnate
description: Leaf that is three times pinnate, with pinnate leaflets that are twice more pinnately divided.

label: trifoliate
description: Leaf divided into three leaflets. (Synonyms, ternate, trifoliolate)

label: deciduous
description: Plant loses its entire leaf canopy for part of the year, in response to either drought or cold.

label: evergreen
description: Plant retains a leaf canopy throughout the year.

label: cold_deciduous
description: Plant loses its entire leaf canopy for part of the year, in response to cold.

label: drought_deciduous
description: Plant loses its entire leaf canopy for part of the year, in response to drought.

label: facultative_drought_deciduous
description: Plant sometimes loses its leaf canopy for part of the year, in response to drought.

label: semi_deciduous
description: Plant thins, but does not entirely lose, its leaf canopy in response to an environmental cue, usually drought.

label: brevi_deciduous
description: Plant briefly loses its entire leaf canopy but flushes a new leaf canopy almost simultaneously to leaf loss.

label: linear
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is very long and narrow, has parallel sides and a length:width ratio between 12:1 and 6:1.

label: narrowly_oblong
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is long and narrow, has parallel sides and a length:width ratio between 6:1 and 3:1. (Synonyms, lorate)

label: oblong
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is somewhat elongated with parallel sides and a length:width ratio between 2:1 and 3:2.

label: linear_elliptical
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is a very narrow oval, with curved margins, lacking a distinct point, and a length:width ratio between 12:1 and 6:1.

label: narrowly_elliptical
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is a narrow oval, with curved margins, lacking a distinct point, and a length:width ratio between 6:1 and 3:1.

label: elliptical
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is an oval, with curved margins, lacking a distinct point, and a length:width ratio between 2:1 and 3:2. (Synonyms, oval)

label: widely_elliptical
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is a broad oval, with curved margins, lacking a distinct point, and a length:width ratio of approximately 6:5.

label: orbicular
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is approximately circular. (Synonyms, circular)

label: oblate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is a broad oval, with curved margins, lacking a distinct point, and a length:width ratio of approximately 5:6. The petiole attaches along the broader side.

label: narrowly_lanceolate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is very narrowly egg-shaped or teardrop-shaped, with a length:width ratio between 12:1 and 6:1. The petiole attaches near the wide, curved portion of the leaf lamina.

label: lanceolate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is narrowly egg-shaped or teardrop-shaped, with a length:width ratio between 6:1 and 3:1. The petiole attaches near the wide, curved portion of the leaf lamina.

label: narrowly_ovate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is narrowly egg-shaped, with a length:width ratio between 3:1 and 2:1. The petiole attaches near the wide, curved portion of the leaf lamina. (Synonyms, lance_ovate, widely_lanceolate)

label: ovate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is egg-shaped, with a length:width ratio between 2:1 and 3:2. The petiole attaches near the wide, curved portion of the leaf lamina.

label: widely_ovate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is broadly egg-shaped with a length:width ratio of approximately 6:5. The petiole attaches near the wide, curved portion of the leaf lamina.

label: narrowly_oblanceolate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is very narrowly teardrop-shaped, with a length:width ratio between 12:1 and 6:1. The leaf lamina has curved outer margins and narrows nearly to a point where it attaches to the petiole. (Synonyms, linear_oblanceolate)

label: oblanceolate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is narrowly teardrop-shaped, with a length:width ratio between 6:1 and 3:1. The leaf lamina has curved outer margins and narrows nearly to a point where it attaches to the petiole.

label: narrowly_obovate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is narrowly egg-shaped or teardrop-shaped with a length:width ratio between 3:1 and 2:1. The leaf lamina has curved outer margins and narrows nearly to a point where it attaches to the petiole. (Synonyms, oblance-obovate)

label: obovate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is egg-shaped with a length:width ratio between 2:1 and 3:2. The leaf lamina has curved outer margins and narrows nearly to a point where it attaches to the petiole.

label: widely_obovate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is broadly egg-shaped with a length:width ratio of approximately 6:5. The leaf lamina has curved outer margins and narrows nearly to a point where it attaches to the petiole.

label: narrowly_triangular
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is narrowly triangular to wedge-shaped, with a length:width ratio 6:1 to 3:1 and the petiole attaching near the widest portion of the leaf. (Synonyms, triangular)

label: triangular
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is triangular to wedge-shaped, with a length:width ratio 2:1 to 3:2 and the petiole attaching near the widest portion of the leaf.

label: deltate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is triangular to wedge-shaped, with a length:width ratio of 1:1 and the petiole attaching along one of the broad sides.

label: obtriangular
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is triangular to fan-shaped or wedge-shaped, with a length:width ratio 2:1 to 3:2 and the petiole attaching near the narrowest portion of the leaf. (Synonyms, flabelliform, fan-shaped, wedge-shaped, cuneate)

label: narrowly_rhomboidal
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is like a narrow diamond, with approximately straight edges, widest near the middle, and a length:width ratio 6:1 to 3:1. The petiole attaches near one of the points.

label: rhomboidal
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is approximately diamond or parallelogram-shaped, with approximately straight edges, widest near the middle, and a length:width ratio 2:1 to 3:2. The petiole attaches near one of the points. (Synonyms, rhombic, diamond)

label: trullate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is approximately parallelogram-shaped, widest near where the petiole attaches (base), and with a length:width ratio 2:1 to 3:2.

label: narrowly_obtrullate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is narrowly parallelogram-shaped, widest near the tip, and with a length:width ratio 3:1 to 6:1.

label: obtrullate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is approximately parallelogram-shaped, widest near the tip, and with a length:width ratio 2:1 to 3:2.

label: widely_obtrullate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is broadly parallelogram-shaped, widest near the tip, and with a length:width ratio of approximately 6:5.

label: acicular
description: A 2-dimensional or 3-dimensional shape with a needlelike tip, often round in cross-section, with margins straight and parallel, and a length:width ratio greater than 12:1. (Synonyms, needle-shaped)

label: terete
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is a long, narrow cylinder approximately circular in cross-section. Terete leaves often taper toward the tip. (Synonym, cylindrical)

label: cordate
description: A 2-dimensional heart shape, approximately ovate with a cordate base, with the petiole attaching at the notch between the lobes. (Synonyms, cordiform)

label: obcordate
description: A 2-dimensional heart shape, approximately ovate with a cordate apex, and the petiole attaching along the broad, curve side.

label: falcate
description: A 2-dimensional sickle-shape, approximately lanceolate to linear and curved on one side. (Synonyms, scimitar-shaped, sickle-shaped, falciform, crescent-shaped)

label: reniform
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is roughly kidney-shaped, wider than long with a rounded apex and two rounded, basal lobes that are smoothly concave at their intersection. (Synonyms, kidney-shaped)

label: spathulate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that can be approximately oblong, obovate, or oblanceolate in outline with a long attenuate base, like a spoon. (Synonyms, spoon-shaped, clavate)

label: strap-shaped
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is strap-shaped with a rounded tip and a length:width ratio greater than 12:1.

label: ensiform
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is sword-shaped with a pointed tip and a length:width ratio greater than 12:1. (Synonyms, sword-shaped)

label: subulate
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is awl-shaped, approximately narrowly oblong to narrowly triangular with a broad base. (Synonyms, awl-shaped)

label: peltate
description: A 2-dimensional orbicular shape, distinguished by the petiole attaching near the center of the leaf lamina.

label: filiform
description: A 2-dimensional shape that is long, thin, and typically flexuous, threadlike, filamentous.

label: acute
description: Two sides of the leaf meet at an angle that is less than 90°.

label: attenuate
description: Basal leaf margin abruptly incurved (concave), the two sides intersecting at an angle of less than 45°.

label: auriculate
description: Basal leaf margin with two rounded lobes. The leaf margin above the lobes is concave. The petiole attaches in the incised region between the lobes.

label: cordate
description: Basal leaf margin with two rounded lobes and the petiole attaches in the incised region between the lobes. The leaf margin above the lobes is rounded.

label: cuneate
description: Basal leaf margin approximately straight, the two sides intersecting at an angle between 45° to 90°.

label: hastate
description: Basal leaf margin with two lobes oriented outward, such that they are at approximately 90° relative to the central axis and the leaf margin is fairly flat at the base.

label: oblique
description: The leaf base is asymmetrical, with the midrib not lying in the middle of the leaf where it attaches to the petiole.

label: obtuse
description: Two sides of the leaf meet at an angle that is greater than 90°.

label: rounded
description: Basal leaf margin is rounded.

label: sagittate
description: Basal leaf margin with two lobes oriented downward, away from apex. The petiole attaches in the concave region between the lobes.

label: sheathing
description: The leaf base is broad and envelops the stem.

label: truncate
description: The basal leaf margin is cut straight across with the two sides intersecting at approximately 180°.

label: leaf
description: A true leaf, including both laminar and needle-shaped leaves.

label: cladode
description: A photosynthetic shoot, regardless of form, that functions as a leaf. For example, cacti pads and Casuarina articles. (Synonyms, article, phylloclade, cladophyll)

label: phyllode
description: A flattened bladelike petiole. (Synonyms, switch plant)

label: non-photosynthetic_plant
description: A plant that lacks any photosynthetic organs.

label: broadleaf
description: Flat leaf lamina, regardless of whether the leaves are or are not toothed, lobed, or compound.

label: needle
description: Needle or awl-shaped leaf that is generally 3-dimensional.

label: scale
description: Leaf reduced to a small scale.

label: leafless
description: An adult stage plant that lacks leaves throughout the year.

label: phanerophyte
description: Plant whose perennating buds are on persistent shoots which rise at least 50 cm above the soil surface. These are normally woody perennials.

label: chamaephyte
description: Plant whose perennating buds are on persistent shoots that do not extend more than 50 cm above the soil surface. These are normally woody perennials.

label: hemicryptophyte
description: Plant whose perennating buds are at or near the soil surface.

label: cryptophyte
description: Plant whose perennating buds are subterranean or under water. This grouping can be further divided into geophyte, helophyte, and hydrophyte.

label: geophyte
description: Plant that perennates as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in dry soil, with all leaves dying back each year; a subcategory of cryptophyte.

label: helophyte
description: Plant that perennates as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in marshy or wet soil or lying under water, with buds emerging during the growing season and shoots and leaves rising about the water surface; a subcategory of cryptophyte. (Synonyms, emergent_hydrophyte)

label: hydrophyte
description: Plant that perennates as buds or as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in marshy or wet soil or lying under water, with shoots emerging during the growing season that remain below or at the water surface; a subcategory of cryptophyte.

label: therophyte
description: Annual plants whose shoot and root systems die completely at the end of flowering and seed production, such that they survive the unfavourable cold or dry season in the form of seeds.

label: epiphyte
description: Plant that grows on the surface of another plant.

label: aerophyte
description: Plant that obtains moisture and nutrients from the air and rain, resting on other plants or the ground surface.

label: ephemeral
description: A very short-lived plant, generally with a lifespan of only a few months and the exact length of lifespan quite variable and determined by environmental conditions.

label: annual
description: A plant that lives for up to one year after germinating, completing its life cycle in a single growing season.

label: biennial
description: A plant that lives for up to two years after germinating, requiring two growing seasons to complete its life cycle and dying following the second growing season.

label: perennial
description: A plant that lives for three or more growing seasons, with an exact lifespan that is indeterminate.

label: short_lived_perennial
description: A perennial whose lifespan is less than approximately five years, with the exact lifespan generally dependent on environmental conditions.

label: disturbance_ephemeral
description: Ephemeral plant the germinates and establishes following disturbance, but the type of disturbance is not specified.

label: rain_ephemeral
description: Ephemeral plant that germinates and establishes following rain or flood events.

label: fire_ephemeral
description: Ephemeral plant that germinates and establishes following fire, where it is unknown if the plant is an obligate or facultative fire ephemeral.

label: fire_ephemeral_facultative
description: Ephemeral plant that increases its germination and establishment following fire, but can also germinate and establish without fire.

label: fire_ephemeral_obligate
description: Ephemeral plant that only germinates and establishes following fire.

label: androdioecious
description: Taxa in which hermaphroditic and staminate (male) plants coexist within a population.

label: andromonoecious
description: Taxa with hermaphrodite flowers and staminate flowers (producing just male gametes) on the same plant but no pistillate (female) flowers.

label: dioecious
description: Taxa that produce male and female flowers on separate plants.

label: gynodioecious
description: Taxa in which hermaphroditic and pistillate (female) plants coexist within a population.

label: gynomonoecious
description: Taxa with hermaphrodite flowers and pistillate flowers (producing just female gametes) on the same plant but no staminate (male) flowers.

label: hermaphrodite
description: Taxa with flowers that produce both male and female gametes; bisexual.

label: monoecious
description: Taxa that have both male and female flowers on the same plant but an individual flower produces only male or female gametes.

label: polygamous
description: Taxa with both unisexual and bisexual flowers on the same plant.

label: polygamodioecious
description: Taxa where some flowers on a plant are hermaphrodite and other are pistillate (female) or staminate (male).

label: polygamonoecious
description: Taxa where some plants in a population have hermaphrodite and pistillate (female) flowers and others have hermaphrodite and staminate (male) flowers.

label: trioecious
description: Taxa where plants in a population have either hermaphroditic (bisexual) flowers, pistillate (female) flowers, or staminate (male) flowers.

label: unknown
description: Inadequate information to assign a sex type.

label: non_nitrogen_fixer
description: Plant does not host nitrogen-fixing microbes.

label: nitrogen_fixer
description: Plant hosts nitrogen-fixing microbes in root nodules.

label: hemiparasitic
description: Plant that is photosynthetic but augments its energy, mineral nutrition, and /or water supply through parasitism. This trait value does not distinguish between obligate hemiparasites, plants which require a host for at least part of their life cycle, and facultative hemiparasites, plants which can grow and reproduce without a host.

label: hemiparasitic_obligate
description: Plant that is photosynthetic but requires a host for at least part of its life cycle.

label: hemiparasitic_facultative
description: Plant that is photosynthetic and can grow and reproduce without a host but augments its energy, mineral nutrition, and /or water supply through parasitism.

label: holoparasitic
description: Plant that obtains all (or nearly all) of its energy through parasitism.

label: parasitic
description: Plant that obtains some energy, mineral nutrition and/or water through parasitism. This term is used if a dataset does not specify if a plant is a hemiparasite or a holoparasite.

label: not_parasitic
description: In the context of this trait, a plant that does not acquire energy, mineral nutrition, and/or water via haustoria connected to another plant. It can include species that form a symbiosis, including a parasitic interaction, with a fungal partner.

label: root_parasitic
description: Parasitic plant whose haustoria penetrate the root of a host plant.

label: stem_parasitic
description: Parasitic plant whose haustoria penetrate the stem of a host plant.

label: saprophyte
description: Plant that acquires nutrients from decaying biomass.

label: carnivorous
description: Plant that acquires some or most of its nutrients from animals or protozoa.

label: nutrient_mining
description: Plant that uses a specialised root structure, such as cluster roots, to mine nutrients inaccessible to other plant taxa.

label: non_photosynthetic_bark
description: Plant's bark is not photosynthetic.

label: photosynthetic_bark
description: Plant's bark is photosynthetic.

label: c3
description: Plant using the 'standard' photosynthetic pathway, where a 3-carbon compound is produced after the first stage in the photosynthetic pathway.

label: c4
description: Plants in which the photosynthetic light-dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle are physically separated to reduce photorespiration.

label: c3-c4
description: Taxa that shift between C3 and C4 photosynthesis.

label: cam
description: Plants which display crassulacean acid metabolism.

label: c3-cam
description: Taxa that shift between C3 and cam photosynthesis.

label: c4-cam
description: Taxa that shift between C4 and cam photosynthesis.

label: facultative_cam
description: Species that shifts between C3 and CAM photosynthesis depending on water availability.

label: unknown
description: Photosynthetic pathway is unknown. (This trait value should be used if the photosynthetic pathway is assessed but unknown, not to record a lack of data.)

label: herb
description: A seed-bearing plant which does not have a woody above-ground stem; when available this term has been divided into more detailed terms. (Synonyms, forb)

label: subshrub
description: A plant that is only woody at the base, with the remainder of the stems regenerating yearly. This term is not meant to encompass short-lived plants that are only borderline woody. (Synonyms, suffrutescent)

label: shrub
description: A woody plant that is distinguished by NOT being a tree, due to one of more of the following characteristics, 1) they are less than 8 metres in height; 2) if a plant community includes trees, the shrubs are shorter than the surrounding trees and not part of the canopy; 3) in comparison to trees, the leaves are more distributed along the entire trunk; 4) the plant has multiple relatively narrow stems arising at or near ground level. The definition of `shrub` is complex, as there are many single-stemmed shrubs within Australia and many taxa that are described in the taxonomic literature as a shrub or small tree.

label: mallee
description: Refers to Eucalyptus species which are small trees that form a large lignotuber. They have multiple stems arising at or near ground level and regenerate from the lignotuber following fire.

label: tree
description: A tall, woody, perennial plant, usually with a single main trunk, and its leaves predominantly elevated above the ground surface.

label: graminoid
description: Herbaceous plant with a grass-like morphology that is within the order Poales. Taxa both with and without a tussock form are mapped to this term. This term is most frequently applied to three large monocot families, Poaceae, Cyperaceae, and Juncaceae, but the term could apply to other taxa within Poales with a grass-like morphology, including narrow, linear leaves and non-showy flowers, including Restionaceae, Centrolepidaceae, Anarthriaceae, and Ecdeiocoleaceae. Taxa outside Poales with a grass-like morphology should be designated as `herbs` and also have the term `tufted` mapped to the trait `stem_growth_habit`.

label: tussock
description: A subcategory of graminoid, which is a plant where many shoots from the basal meristem form prominent tufts.

label: graminoid_not_tussock
description: A subcategory of graminoid, indicating a plant which explicitly lacks a tussock morphology, with the leaves not growing in tufts.

label: hummock
description: Plant that grows as a dense mound up to 1 metre in height. The term generally applies only to species within the genera Triodia that form such mounds and these are considered a distinctive and uniquely Australian growth form.

label: basal_large
description: A plant whose leaves form a distinctly large basal tuft or rosette, including large acaulescent monocots and cycads.

label: geophyte
description: Subcategory of herb, specifically referring to plants that survive the winter/dry season as an organ (rhizome, bulb, corm, or tuber) buried in dry soil, with all leaves dying back each year.

label: palmoid
description: Plant that bears a rosette-like canopy of typically large, often compound leaves atop a usually thick (pachycaulous), columnar, unbranched or little-branched stem. Palms, tree ferns, trunked cycads, trunked grass-trees, and Pandanus are mapped to this term. (Synonyms, rosette-tree, palm, grass-tree)

label: climber
description: Plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. Term used only if datasets do not specify if a climbing plant is herbaceous (a vine) or woody (a liana).

label: climber_herbaceous
description: Herbaceous plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with `vine`. Types of climbers (scrambling, twining) are captured under the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`. (Synonyms, vine)

label: climber_woody
description: Woody or thick-stemmed (>2 cm) plant that climbs up another plant's stem or branches, rather than being able to support itself. This is usually synonymous with `liana`. Woody climbers generally use hooks, tendrils, and/or adventitious roots to climb; the climbing mechanisms used by a taxon are captured under the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`. (Synonyms, liana)

label: fern
description: A taxonomic grouping; ferns are vascular plants that reproduce via spores.

label: lycophyte
description: A taxonomic grouping that includes quillworts, clubmosses, and selaginella.

label: succulent_stems
description: Stems are thick and fleshy.

label: succulent_leaves
description: Leaves are thick and fleshy.

label: succulent
description: A plant is designated as succulent but it is not specified which tissues are thick and fleshy.

label: semi-succulent
description: A plant has tissues that are somewhat thick and fleshy, including many chenopods.

label: not_succulent
description: Neither stems nor leaves are thick and fleshy.

label: arborescent
description: Tree-like growth habit.

label: erect
description: Stems that grow upright.

label: caespitose
description: Multiple short-shoots arise from the base of the plant forming a dense tuft, as in a bunch-grass. (Synonyms, cespitose, bunch-grass, tussock)

label: cushion-forming
description: Multiple erect, short stems arise from the soil and are so tightly packed that they form dense, even, rounded canopy with no gaps. (Synonyms, cushion)

label: mat-forming
description: Multiple stems that are mostly horizontal and are densely packed but open enough that there are still a few gaps between them.

label: tufted
description: Plant has a dense clump of leaves, either at the base of the plant or clusters of leaves growing close together higher on the plant. This term can refer to grasses, shrubs, or trees.

label: creeping
description: Stem that creeps along the ground, rooting at nodes. (Synonyms, repent)

label: decumbent
description: Stems whose bases lie flat on the ground but whose tips grow upward. (Synonyms, ascending)

label: prostrate
description: Stems lie flat on the ground but do not root at nodes. (Synonyms, procumbent, reclining, trailing)

label: rosette
description: Plants whose leaves radiate from a central point at or near ground level. (Synonyms, acaulescent, rosulate)

label: climbing
description: Stem that does not have a self-supporting structure and ascends by leaning on or attaching itself to surrounding vegetation or another substrate. Climbing mechanisms include tendrils, petioles, adventitious roots, scrambling, and twining and are distinguished between in the trait `plant_climbing_mechanism`.

label: sprawling
description: Stem that sprawls across other plants or objects but lacks specialised climbing structures or mechanisms. (Synonyms, clambering, scandent)

label: rhizomatous
description: Plants with short horizontal underground stems from which shoots emerge.

label: stoloniferous
description: Plants with long horizontal branches either slightly belowground or aboveground, that root at their nodes or tips, producing new plants. (Synonyms, sarmentose)

label: spreading
description: Plants with a notable horizontal extent, referring either to a broad tree canopy or a shrub or herb that spreads across the ground.

label: floating
description: Plant where most of the leaves are floating on water.

label: submerged
description: Plant where most of the leaves are submerged beneath the surface of a waterbody.

label: dense
description: Plant with a high density of branches.

label: compact
description: Plant with closely packed branches.

label: bushy
description: Plant with much-branched branches. (Synonyms, shrubby)

label: open
description: Plant with an open architecture of branches.

label: spindly
description: Plants with weak, skinny branches.

label: adventitious_roots
description: Roots arising from stem nodes which cling to a host plant.

label: hooks
description: Curved stem outgrowths which allow climbers to cling to a host plant.

label: spines
description: Straight stem outgrowths (including true spines as well as thorns and prickles) which allow climbers to cling to a host plant.

label: tendrils
description: Modified leaves, petioles, or specialised axillary shoots that coil tightly, forming a specialised structure for climbing.

label: scrambling
description: Stem growth habit, where the plant stems are too weak to support themselves, and instead lean on and are supported by host vegetation. There are no specialised structures employed.

label: twining
description: Stem growth habit, where the plant stems twist or coil around a host plant to provide support.

label: epiphyte
description: A plant that grows upon another plant.

label: lithophyte
description: A plant that grows upon a rock.

label: terrestrial
description: A plant that grows on land, and generally referencing a plant that grows in soil.

label: semiaquatic
description: A plant that grows partially submerged in water or spends part of its life growing in water.

label: aquatic
description: A plant that grows in water.

label: marine
description: A plant that grows in the sea.

label: hemiepiphyte
description: A plant that spends part of its life cycle as an epiphyte, growing upon another plant.

label: hydrohalophyte
description: Tidal swamp or 'mangrove' and coastal lagoon elements and temperate-zone salt-marsh taxa are classed together.

label: phreatophyte
description: Deep-rooted plants—usually trees—obtaining water from a deep underground source that may or may not be saline.

label: psammophile
description: Sand-loving plants commonly found in littoral strand or inland sandfields.

label: weedy
description: This inexact term is meant to indicate a high degree of adaptability to sites, and proven tendency toward aggressive colonization of either dry or wet sites, or rarely, both. In general, weeds invade and colonize highly disturbed sites or areas.

label: xerohalophyte
description: Plants adapted to inland salt desert and saline habitats.

label: xerophyte
description: Drought-tolerant and drought-adapted plants.

label: abiotic
description: Floral syndrome indicates pollination occurs through wind, water, or collision of free-floating particles.

label: biotic
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are pollinated by a biotic agent.

label: animal
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are animal-pollinated.

label: ballistic
description: Floral syndrome suggests pollen is launched away from the plant by explosion.

label: bat
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are bat-pollinated.

label: bee
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are bee-pollinated.

label: beetle
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are beetle-pollinated.

label: bird
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are bird-pollinated.

label: butterfly
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are butterfly-pollinated.

label: fly
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are fly-pollinated.

label: insect
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are insect-pollinated, type of insect not specified.

label: mammal
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are mammal-pollinated.

label: moth
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are moth-pollinated.

label: thrip
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are thrip-pollinated.

label: vertebrate
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are vertebrate-pollinated (bats, birds, mammals or lizards).

label: wasp
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are wasp-pollinated.

label: water
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are water-pollinated.

label: wind
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are wind-pollinated.

label: self
description: Floral syndrome suggests flowers are primarily self-pollinating.

label: pollination_rare
description: Plants mostly reproduce through vegetative spread and flowering is rare.

label: abiotic
description: Observations indicate pollination occurs through wind, water, or collision of free-floating particles.

label: biotic_unspecialised
description: Taxa are pollinated by a biotic agent, but do not have a specialist pollinator.

label: biotic_specialised
description: Taxa depend upon a specialist pollinator for pollen transfer.

label: animal
description: Flowers are observed to be animal-pollinated.

label: ballistic
description: Pollen is observed to be launched away from the plant by explosion.

label: bat
description: Flowers are observed to be bat-pollinated.

label: bee
description: Flowers are observed to be bee-pollinated.

label: beetle
description: Flowers are observed to be beetle-pollinated.

label: bird
description: Flowers are observed to be bird-pollinated.

label: butterfly
description: Flowers are observed to be butterfly-pollinated.

label: fly
description: Flowers are observed to be fly-pollinated.

label: insect
description: Flowers are observed to be insect-pollinated, type of insect not specified.

label: mammal
description: Flowers are observed to be mammal-pollinated.

label: moth
description: Flowers are observed to be moth-pollinated.

label: thrip
description: Flowers are observed to be thrip-pollinated.

label: vertebrate
description: Flowers are observed to be vertebrate-pollinated (bats, birds, mammals or lizards).

label: wasp
description: Flowers are observed to be wasp-pollinated.

label: water
description: Flowers are observed to be water-pollinated.

label: wind
description: Flowers are observed to be wind-pollinated.

label: self
description: Flowers are self-pollinated.

label: apical_buds
description: Plants resprout from above-ground apical meristems. Also termed a caudex. Term refers to palm-like plants with aerial buds that resprout, including grass trees, palms, tree ferns, and pandanus. (Synonym, aerial apical sprouter)

label: basal_buds
description: Plants resprout from its base, with buds originating from stem tissue (e.g. lignotuber) and root tissue (root crown) not distinguished between. Most buds designated as being basal are likely to be resprouts from a lignotuber, but this trait value is used if the dataset reported `basal buds` rather than `basal stem buds` or `lignotuber`.

label: basal_stem_buds
description: Plants resprout from the base of the stem. Australian plants with basal stem buds usually have a lignotuber, documented in the trait `storage_organ`. (Synonym, rootstock, lignotuberous resprouter)

label: epicormic_buds
description: Plants resprout from the stem or trunk.

label: fleshy_underground_organ
description: Plants resprouts from buds on a fleshy underground organ that is a taproot tuber, bulb, corm, stem tuber, root tuber, or belowground caudex. (Synonym, geophyte)

label: root_crown
description: Plants resprout from the root crown, the root tissue at the root-stem transition.

label: bud-bearing_root
description: Root buds produce vertical suckers (from root crown) or adventitious roots. (Synonyms, root-suckering resprouter, adventitious buds)

label: rhizome
description: Plants resprout from buds on a rhizome, where it is not specified if the rhizome is woody or non-woody.

label: rhizome_woody
description: Plants resprout from buds on a woody rhizome.

label: rhizome_non_woody
description: Plants resprout from buds on a fleshy rhizome, rhizophore, or fibrous rhizome.

label: stem_buds
description: Plants resprout from stem buds; this trait value is separate to epicormic buds. (Synonyms, aerial axillary resprouter)

label: stem_tuber
description: Plants resprout from buds on a stem tuber.

label: stolon
description: Horizontal branches (stems) resprout from the base of the plant.

label: underground_buds
description: Plants that resprout from underground organ, but the type of organ isn't specified.

label: none
description: Plants lack regenerative buds.

label: bulb
description: Below ground storage organ derived from stem and usually leaf tissue.

label: corm
description: Below ground storage organ that is a short, rounded, vertical, fleshy, underground stem.

label: caudex
description: Swollen stem that usually functions in water storage, although the term can also apply to below ground structures or to swollen roots.

label: fleshy_underground_organ
