description: Plants that use fleshy, generally underground organs (swellings) to regenerate, but the type of organ is not specified; examples include corms, tubers, bulbs, and caudex.

label: lignotuber
description: Swollen woody structures are located at the transition between the stem base and root crown of woody shrubs, mallees and small trees, and are formed from stem tissues. Buds are located over the entire structure. No colonisation ability.

label: pseudobulb
description: An above ground storage organ present in many terrestrial and epiphytic orchids created throough the thickening of the stem between leaf nodes.

label: rhizome
description: A type of continually growing or creeping underground stem, but it is not specified if the rhizome is woody or non-woody.

label: rhizome_woody
description: A type of continually growing or creeping woody underground stem.

label: rhizome_fleshy
description: A type of continually growing or creeping fleshy, non-woody underground stem.

label: rhizome_fibrous
description: A type of continually growing or creeping fibrous, non-woody underground stem.

label: root_tuber
description: A swollen root the stores nutrients, carbohydrates and water. (Synonym, taproot tuber)

label: stem_tuber
description: A swollen underground stem that stores nutrients, carbohydrates and water.

label: storage_organ
description: Plant has a storage organ, but the type is unknown.

label: tuber
description: A swollen underground organ that stores nutrients, carbohydrates and water, where it is not specified if the tuber develops from root or stem tissue.

label: no_storage_organ
description: No storage organ present

label: resprouts_non_fire_disturbance
description: Plants that are known to be fire-killed, but have the ability to resprout following a disturbance other than fire that causes 100% leaf loss.

label: resprouts_after_cyclone
description: Plants are able to resprout following 100% leaf loss in a cyclone.

label: resprouts_after_drought
description: Plants are able to resprout following 100% leaf loss during a drought.

label: aboveground_clonal
description: Vegetative buds or plant fragments that can disperse and produce new plants (including axillary buds, bulbils and turions).

label: adventitious_roots
description: Adventitious roots can form at nodes on the main roots or aboveground from nodes on stems.

label: bulb
description: Below ground storage organ derived from stem (and sometimes leaf) tissue, that divides into new individuals.

label: belowground_clonal
description: Plants use an unspecified underground organ for clonal spread.

label: corm
description: Below ground organ derived from stem tissue that can function either for vegetative spread or to regenerate following a disturbance.

label: rhizome
description: Plant has an underground stem that has stem buds and forms adventitious roots at nodes; this stem may be woody or non-woody. Rhizomes are both a mechanism for vegetative spread and a strategy to survive fire.

label: root_buds
description: Root buds that produce vertical suckers.

label: root_tuber
description: A swollen root that functions as a storage organ and has buds that allow clonal growth.

label: stem_tuber
description: A swollen underground stem that functions as a storage organ and has buds that allow clonal growth.

label: stolon
description: Plants having horizontal branches (stems) from the base of the plant that produce new plants from buds at its tip or nodes.

label: viviparous
description: Plant produces clonal offspring that grow while still attached to the parent plant.

label: non_clonal
description: Plant does not display clonal growth.

label: type_i
description: The primary root is fibrous or fleshy and is relatively long; mesophytic.

label: type_ii
description: The primary root is relatively short and is fibrous. Roots are well branched in a dry habitat but branch little in one that is wet.

label: type_iii
description: The primary root is usually long and fibrous. The first order lateral roots are well branched and are usually short; they are rather evenly distributed along the primary root; xerophytic.

label: type_iv
description: The primary root is usually long and slender like that of Type II. The first order lateral roots are well branched. Those closest to the surface of the ground, or not far below, are relatively long; xerophytic and mesophytic.

label: type_v
description: The primary root is divided-forked or branched-and fibrous, and with few first order lateral roots, or, in age, apparently with none; xerophytic.

label: type_vi
description: The primary root is usually as in Type V. The first order lateral roots are mostly on the upper portion of the primary root and are thus relatively superficial; xerophytic or in well aerated sandy soil where the rainfall is not light.

label: type_vii
description: Adventitious roots that are in one group and arise on a short horizontal, or vertical, axis of the shoot. They are fibrous or fleshly; mesophytic and hydrophytic.

label: type_viii
description: Adventitious roots that are in one group and are fibrous and fleshy, or fibrous and thick. The fibrous adventitious roots are absorbing-anchoring roots and are usually with laterals to the second order; meophytic.

label: type_ix
description: Adventitious roots that arise on the aerial stem and branches of some herbaceous taxa, shrubs, and trees; on creepers, vines, and runners; and on subterranean rhizomes and stolons.

label: arbuscular_mycorrhizal
description: Symbiosis in which the mycorrhizal fungi does penetrate the cortex cells of the plant roots and its hyphae form arbuscules and vesicles inside the plant root; endomycorrhizal, AM, VAM.

label: carnivorous
description: Plant has non-mycorrhizal carnivorous root.

label: cluster_roots
description: Non-proteoid taxa with cluster roots.

label: coiling_vam
description: Associations that spread predominantly by intracellular hyphal coils within roots.

label: dauciform_root
description: A type of cluster root found in the family Cyperaceae.

label: ectomycorrhizal
description: Symbiosis in which the mycorrhizal fungi does not penetrate the cortex cells of the plant roots.

label: ericoid_mycorrhizal
description: A form of arbuscular mycorrhizal relationship only found on plants in the order Ericales. The fungi's hyphae penetrate the plant root but do not form arbuscules.

label: fine_roots
description: Particularly fine roots for nutrient uptake.

label: haustorium
description: A highly modified stem or root of a parasitic plant, such as mistletoe , or a specialized branch or tube originating from a hairlike filament (hypha) of a fungus. The haustorium penetrates the tissues of a host and absorbs nutrients and water.

label: hemiparasitic_root
description: Plant with a partially parasitic root.

label: long_root_hairs
description: Plant with specialised long root hairs.

label: mycorrhizal
description: Plant mycorrhizal but type not specified.

label: non_mycorrhizal
description: Plants lacking a mycorrhizal symbiont.

label: orchid_mycorrhizal
description: A mycorrhizal relationship specific to orchid taxa, and for most orchids, essential for seedlings to establish.

label: parasitic_root
description: Plant with a parasitic root.

label: proteoid_root
description: Also known as cluster roots, are plant roots that form clusters of closely spaced short lateral rootlets and aid in nutrient upake in nutrient-poor soils; common in members of the family Proteaceae but present in other families as well.

label: root_hairs
description: Plant with specialised root hairs.

label: sand-binding
description: Persistent sheaths of sand that form around the roots of taxa in the families Restionaceae, Cyperaceae, Haemodoraceae, and Lomandraceae in western Australia. Assumed to function in nutrient uptake.

label: saprophyte
description: Plant that acquires nutrients from decaying biomass.

label: subepidermal_mycorrhizal
description: Mycorrhizae where hyphae grow in a cavity under epidermal cells. Only in the genus Thysanotus (family Laxmaniaceae).

label: unknown
description: Root structures unknown.

label: glycophyte
description: Plants that cannot survive even one tenth the salt concentration found in seawater.

label: halophyte
description: Plants that complete their life cycle in a salty environment; many survive in seawater or even higher concentrations of salt.

label: halophyte_moderate
description: Plant that is moderately tolerant of soil salinity/sodicity.

label: hydrohalophyte
description: Tidal swamp or 'mangrove' and coastal lagoon elements and temperate-zone salt-marsh taxa are classed together.

label: salt_spray_tolerant
description: Plant that is tolerant of salt spray (typically inhabiting near-coastal environments).

label: salinity_tolerance_undefined
description: Plant's ability to tolerate salt is unknown.

label: xerohalophyte
description: Plants adapted to inland salt desert and saline habitats.

label: comma-shaped
description: A seed displaying a single arc of curvature, such that it bilaterally symmetrical. (Synonyms, comma-shaped, falcate, sickle-shaped scimitar-shaped)

label: conical
description: Cone-shaped, with a broad flat base and narrow apex; turbinate refers to the inverse shape. (Synonyms, obconical, cone-shaped, turbinate, top-shaped)

label: cuneate
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is wedge-shaped or boat-shaped.

label: cylindrical
description: A cylinder, a shape with a flat top and bottom that are circular or elliptical in outline and are linked by a curved surface. (Synonyms, terete)

label: discoid
description: A subset of cylinder, a shape with a flat, circular or elliptical top and bottom, linked by a curved surface, where the length of the curved surface is much shorter than the cross-section of the flat surfaces. (Synonyms, flat)

label: ellipsoid
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is elliptic in long section and circular in cross section; length:width ratio between 2:1 and 3:2. (Synonyms, obloid, oblong)

label: ellipsoid_flattened
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is elliptic in long section and and laterally compressed/flattened such that it is non-circular in cross section; length:width ratio between 2:1 and 3:2.

label: fusiform
description: Spindle-shaped; A 3-dimension shape that is narrowly ellipsoid, circular in cross-section and tapering sharply toward both ends. (Synonyms, spindle-shaped)

label: globoid
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is circular in both long section and cross section. (Synonyms, globose, globular, spherical)

label: globoid_flattened
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is circular in both long section and somewhat flattened such that it is non-circular in cross section.

label: hemispheric
description: Half a sphere or globe, with a flat base, domed top, and circular in cross-section. (Synonyms, convex)

label: hemispheric_flattened
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is a laterally compressed/flattened half-sphere or globe; shape has a flat base, a domed top, and is elliptical in cross-section.

label: lenticular
description: Shaped like a biconvex lens and circular in cross section; shaped like a lentil.

label: orbicular
description: A poorly defined term that remains in AusTraits only as a placeholder; it appears to be used as both globoid (spherical) and lenticular by different authors.

label: ovoid
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is egg-shaped in long section and circular in cross section. Term as used in AusTraits includes variants on egg-shaped including pyriform (pear-shaped) and obovoid (inversely egg-shaped) (Synonyms, pyriform, obovoid)

label: ovoid_elongated
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is egg-shaped in long section and circular in cross section, where the length dimension is much longer than the width/height dimensions. Term as used in AusTraits includes specific shapes club-shaped (clavate/obclavate) and tear-shaped (lachrimiform). (Synonyms, lachrimiform, tear-shaped, lachrymiform, clavate; obclavate, club-shaped)

label: ovoid_flattened
description: A 3-dimensional shape that is egg-shaped in long section and laterally compressed/flattened such that is non-circular in cross section.

label: polyhedral
description: A 3-dimensional shape with distinct, fairly flat faces and edges; includes prisms and tetrahedral shaped seeds. (Synonyms, rhomboid, prismatic, pyramidal, rectangular, square)

label: polyhedral_elongated
description: A 3-dimensional shape with distinct, fairly flat faces and edges, where the length dimension is much longer than the width/height dimensions; includes elongate prisms and elongate tetrahedral shaped seeds.

label: polyhedral_inflated
description: A 3-dimensional shape with distinct faces and edges but the faces tend to bulge outwards.

label: reniform
description: Having a cross-section that is roughly circular with a notch; strictly a kidney-shape but the definition applied here includes heart-shaped seeds and other seeds with a distinct notch. (Synonyms, cordiform, kidney-shaped, heart-shaped)

label: winged
description: A seed with wings. (Synonyms, samara)

label: sectoroid
description: Shaped like an orange segment or wedge of a sphere. (Synonyms, wedge-shaped)

label: sinusoidal
description: A seed with two arcs of curvature or a single arc, such that it lacks an axis of symmetry. (Synonyms, sigmoidal)

label: glabrous
description: Seed surface lacks trichomes or bristles.

label: hairs
description: Seed surface with trichomes or bristles.

label: hairs_branched
description: Seed surface with branched trichomes or bristles.(Synonyms, stellate, plumose)

label: hairs_simple
description: Seed surface with simple trichomes or bristles. (Synonyms, tomentose, velutinous, velvety, sericeous)

label: dull
description: Seed surface appears dull, indicating it has a low reflectivity.

label: shiny
description: Seed surface appears shiny or glossy, indicating it has a high reflectivity. (Synonyms, glossy, lustrous, polished)

label: bumpy
description: Seed surface covered with minute, rounded protuberances. (Synonyms, colliculate, verrucate, papillate, tuberculate, undulate)

label: grooved
description: Seed surface covered with grooves.

label: netted
description: Seed surface covered with raised, reticulate, interconnected ridges. (Synonyms, reticulate, honey-combed)

label: papery
description: Seed surface with a thin and papery texture. (Synonyms, chartaceous)

label: pitted
description: Seed surface pitted. (Synonyms, foveolate, foveate, dimpled, punctate, lacunose)

label: ribbed
description: Seed surface with longitudinal raised ribs or ridges. (Synonyms, costate, carinate, lineate, fluted, striate, strigose, lineolate, scalariform, ridged)

label: rough
description: Seed surface rough with no organisation of markings, resembling sandpaper. (Synonyms, scabrous)

label: scaly
description: Seed surface rough with loose scales differing in direction or not parallel in direction. (Synonyms, scurfy, squarrose)

label: smooth
description: Seed surface smooth, lacking texture. (Synonym, glabrous)

label: spiny
description: Seed surface with spines. (Synonyms, echinulate)

label: wrinkled
description: Seed surface with a wrinkled, rugose texture. (Synonyms, rugose, rugulose, bullate)

label: seedbank
description: A seedbank exists, but its locations is not specified.

label: canopy_seedbank
description: Seeds stored in the canopy, usually still within a woody cone.

label: soil_seedbank
description: Seeds stored in the soil.

label: canopy_seedbank_absent
description: Seed explicitly not stored in the canopy.

label: soil_seedbank_absent
description: Seed explicitly not stored in the soil.

label: none
description: Seeds are not stored.

label: transient
description: Seed that survives in the seedbank until its first annual germination season, but not until its second annual germination season. Some transient seeds will germinate within weeks to months, while others may remain in the seedbank for slightly over a year, depending on how the annual recruitment season aligns with seed maturation. Transient seeds are non-dormant, remaining in the seedbank until environmental conditions are appropriate for germination.

label: persistent
description: Seed that survives in the seedbank until at least its second germination season.

label: short_persistent
description: Seed that persists in the seedbank for approximately 1 to 5 years, although the time interval varies by study.

label: long_persistent
description: Seed that persists in the seedbank for more than 5 years, although the time interval varies by study.

label: widely_dispersed
description: Seed longevity not important, as seeds are widely dispersed and always available for germination.

label: not_serotinous
description: Plant does not display serotiny.

label: serotinous
description: Plant serotinous, level not specified.

label: serotiny_low
description: Plant displays a weak level of serotiny, indicating it releases most of its seeds gradually, with only a small proportion of the seeds retained as a canopy seedbank until an environmental cue triggers the release of the entire seedbank.

label: serotiny_moderate
description: Plant displays a moderate level of serotiny, indicating it releases some of its seeds gradually, with the remainder retained as a canopy seedbank until an environmental cue triggers the release of the entire seedbank.

label: serotiny_high
description: Plant displays a strong level of serotiny, indicating all seeds are retained as a canopy seedbank until an environmental cue triggers their release.

label: scale-like
description: The leaf at the first stem node above the epicotyl is scale-like, also referred to as a cataphyll.

label: leaf-like
description: The leaf at the first stem node above the epicotyl is leaf-like (broad).

label: single
description: There is a single leaf at the first stem node above the epicotyl.

label: paired
description: There is a pair of leaves at the first stem node above the epicotyl.

label: not_applicable
description: Taxa is virtually never confronted with snow in nature and the response is unknown.

label: intolerant
description: Taxa is frost tender and known to be killed by any snow.

label: days
description: Taxa can tolerate being covered by snow for days (typically less than 1 week).

label: weeks
description: Taxa can tolerate being covered by snow for weeks (typically less than 1 month).

label: months
description: Taxa can tolerate being covered by snow for months.

label: absent
description: Plant that lacks a physical defence structure.

label: sharp_pointed_defence
description: Plant that has either spines, thorns, or prickles but the type of physical defence structure is not specified.

label: prickle
description: A sharp-tipped outgrowth from the epidermis, bark or other plant organ that is explicitly not a spine (modified leaf) or thorn (modified stem).

label: pungent_leaf_apex
description: A sharp-tipped leaf.

label: spine
description: A sharp-pointed structure, which is a modified leaf or leaf part, including petioles, midribs, secondary veins, leaflets, or stipules.

label: stinging_or_irritant_hairs
description: Trichomes that sting or irritate, by injecting a toxin.

label: thorn
description: A sharp-pointed, stiff, woody modified stem.

label: no_spines
description: No spines. (level 0)

label: low_density_soft_spines
description: Low or very local density of soft spines <5mm long; plant may sting or prickle when hit carelessly but not impart strong pain. (level 1)

label: high_density_soft_spines
description: High density of soft spines, intermediate density of spines of intermediate hardness, or low density of hard, sharp spines >5mm long; plant causes actual pain when hit carelessly. (level 2)

label: high_density_hard_spines_to_5mm
description: Intermediate or high density of hard, sharp spines >5mm long; plant causes strong pain when hit carelessly. (level 3)

label: high_density_hard_spines_to_20mm
description: Intermediate or high density of hard, sharp spines >20mm long; plant may cause significant wounds when hit carelessly. (level 4)

label: high_density_hard_spines_to_100mm
description: Intermediate or high density of hard, sharp spines >100mm long; plant is dangerous to careless large mammals, including humans. (level 5)

label: amphistomatic
description: Leaves with stomata on both leaf surfaces.

label: amphistomatic_uneven
description: Leaves with stomata on both leaf surfaces but more stomata on the lower leaf surface.

label: epistomatic
description: Leaves that only have stomata on the upper (adaxial) leaf surface.

label: hypostomatic
description: Leaves that only have stomata on the lower (abaxial) leaf surface.

label: stomata_covered_with_dense_hairs
description: Stomata densely covered by hairs.

label: stomata_not_covered_by_hairs
description: Stomata not hair-covered.

label: tap_root_absent
description: Tap root not present.

label: tap_root_present
description: Tap root present.

label: tap_root_sometimes_present
description: Tap root sometimes present.

label: not_vegetative
description: Plant taxa that regenerate and spread only by seed.

label: vegetative
description: Plant taxa that can regenerate and spread through the growth and division of vegetative material, not just from seed; examples include runners, rhizomes, and bulbs.

label: vegetative_obligate
description: Plant taxa that never (or very rarely) regenerate from seed, instead regenerating and spreading entirely through the growth and division of vegetative material.

label: not_applicable
description: Taxa is not typically confronted with waterlogging and its response is unknown.

label: less_than_1_month
description: Taxa able to tolerate less than 1 month of waterlogging.

label: 1-6_months
description: Taxa able to tolerate 1-6 months of waterlogging.

label: greater_than_6_months
description: Taxa able to tolerate more than 6 months of waterlogging.

label: aquatic
description: Taxa truly aquatic and able to be permanently inundated.

label: herbaceous
description: Plant with non-lignified stems.

label: woody
description: Plant whose stems are stiff and lignified, including both stems that produce secondary xylem and those that produce only lignified primary tissues but are notably stiff and robust.

label: herbaceous
description: Plant with non-lignified stems.

label: woody
description: Plant whose stems produce secondary xylem (true wood).

label: woody_base
description: Plant where secondary xylem (true wood) is present only at the base of stems. (Synonyms, suffrutescent)

label: woody_root
description: Plant that has a woody rootstock but non-woody above-ground stems.

label: semi_woody
description: Plant that forms stems considered only "partially woody", generally having lower lignin and cellulose contents and possibly not forming secondary xylem. These are generally short-lived, fast-growing stems. (Synonyms, green-stem shrub, soft shrub, soft wood)

label: woody_like_stem
description: Taxa, including monocots and ferns, that produce thick, stiff, robust lignified stems but do not produce secondary xylem.

label: woody_like_inflorescence
description: Taxa, including monocots and ferns, that produce thick, stiff, robust lignified inflorescence shoots but are otherwise non-woody.
